issue_description:
# [BUG]: Next Chapter Button Overlapped by Footer on Mobile Viewport.

### Describe the bug

In the mobile viewport, specifically mimicking an iPhone 6, the "Next Chapter" button on the last state of the exploration is not visible as it is overlapped by the footer. It is also affecting our acceptance tests which are set to run on this specific viewport.

### URL of the page where the issue is observed.

NA

### Steps To Reproduce

i) Set the viewport to mimic an iPhone 6 (375x667) using Puppeteer or a similar tool.
ii) Navigate to an exploration present as chapter in a story and progress to the last state.
iii) Observe that the "Next Chapter" button is not visible. (Make sure there are more than chapters)

### Expected Behavior

The "Next Lesson" button should be clearly visible and accessible to the user, regardless of the viewport size. The button should not be overlapped by the footer or any other elements on the page.

### Screenshots/Videos


https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a3607bad-c081-45a5-9fde-cf1d43a688d0



### What device are you using?

Desktop

### Operating System

MacOS

### What browsers are you seeing the problem on?

_No response_

### Browser version

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Tips for developers

Before addressing the bug, please identify which PR caused the issue (you can follow the steps [here](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/How-to-find-the-commit-which-introduced-a-bug)). If you identify the PR, comment on the issue with a link to it. If not, mention the commit hash of the oldest commit you saw the bug on (and the month and year it was made in).

Then, please leave a comment with details of the approach that you plan to take to fix the issue (see [example](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/issues/19157#issuecomment-1858788463)).

**Note:** If this is your first Oppia issue, please make sure to follow our guidelines for [choosing an issue](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Contributing-code-to-Oppia#choosing-a-good-first-issue) and [setting things up](https://github.com/oppia/oppia/wiki/Contributing-code-to-Oppia#setting-things-up). You will also need to show a demo of the fix working correctly on your local machine. Thanks!

golden_answers_generated: The CSS for the 'conversation-skin-correctness-footer-container' positions the footer as fixed at the bottom of the viewport with a bottom offset of 40px. This can cause it to overlap other elements, such as the 'Next Chapter' button, especially in smaller viewports like that of an iPhone 6. The button's container, 'conversation-skin-next-lesson-wrapper', also has relative positioning which might not prevent overlap with the fixed footer.

Developers can follow the steps outlined in the Oppia repository wiki for finding the commit that introduced a bug. This typically involves using Git's bisect feature to efficiently pinpoint the exact commit where the issue first appeared by testing various commits in a binary search fashion.

To ensure the 'Next Chapter' button is visible, the CSS can be adjusted by either changing the 'conversation-skin-correctness-footer-container' to have a larger bottom offset or adjusting the 'conversation-skin-next-lesson-wrapper' so that it has a higher z-index or margins that prevent overlap. Another approach could be to use media queries to adjust the layout specifically for small screen sizes.

Viewport emulation settings in Puppeteer, such as setting the viewport to mimic an iPhone 6 (375x667), will replicate the screen size and resolution of such a device. This ensures that the UI is tested under conditions similar to real-world usage on such devices, allowing detection of layout issues like the overlapping button, which might not be apparent in larger desktop viewports.

A developer can ensure that they have correctly set up the development environment according to the Oppia wiki guidelines. They should verify that the required data is seeded, ensure no errors occur during server startup, and check the browser console for any JavaScript errors. Additionally, they might need to create or configure explorations correctly to simulate a multi-chapter scenario to reproduce the bug.
